reviewText: Why do you do release such great musical's/movies on a cheapy way without a restoration and subtitles? Sorry, for foreign speaking like me I need those sometime as help.Well, the movie itself is in one word: fantastic.Eleanor Powell is the queen of tap dancing and I love her "Honolulu" and "Old Dixie Melody" (Bill Robinson-)-Number and her hawaiian dance numbers. Miss Powell's Co-Stars Robert Young and Gracie Allen are amazing. And apropos the scenes with the Double/Twins are amazing. It looks incredible when Robert Young shakes the hand of his Doppelganger - made without any computer effects!!!TRIVIA: Did you know, uncredited parts as singer/chorus you can hear the voice of the amazing Douglas McPhail (who maybe is most reconized in Judy Garland/Mickey Rooneys "Babes in Arms" and "Little Nellie Kelly"). McPhail had also a bit part in Eleanor Powells "Born to Dance" (Solo Bit in 'Entrance of Lucy James' Number) and was the Masked Singer (uncredited) in Fred Astaire/Eleanor Powell only movie together: "Broadway Melody of 1940". His wife Betty Jaynes is also as singer/chorus in "Honolulu". Sadly, this very talented singer made suicide in 1944. Miss Janyes is still living.Apropos:  one of those Groucho Marx masked singer who sings with Gracie Allen - it's Ken Darby who is maybe well know as director of the Ken Darby singers.The Picture Quality is very good and also the soundtrack is very good (of course in mono).FAZIT: very nice musical, with fantastic special effects and a wonderful Eleanor Powell where is still the QUEEN OF TAP.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Honolulu". . . .I was psyched to see this old Hollywood comedy primarily because of the music -- I love classic "hapa haole" Hawaiian pop and this film, like 1937's "Waikiki Wedding" includes footage of some great Hawaiian stars, notably bandleaderAndy Iona, whose band plays during a luau scene. Also, I'm a Burns & Allen fan, and they play supporting roles, which is always a plus, and I also enjoy seeing actor Robert Young, who has a prominent (dual) role in this "Prince And The Pauper"-style personality mix-up caper.Dancer Eleanor Powell is the nominal star, although I suppose I'm in the minority here when I say that I usually find her to be a bit drippy and much prefer Robert Young's presence onscreen. Naturally, Andy Iona's appearance is all too short (though fun!) and there's a bit of authentic Hawaiian culture here and there, though overall the film's racial caricatures are atrocious. Eddie "Rochester" Anderson rolls his eyes in a few scenes as a butler, and Powell does a Bojangles number in blackface -- both of which are forgivable -- but Willie Fung's turn as "Wong" the Chinese valet is just appalling, a truly horrible, you-no-like-ee, me-speakee stereotype, with Young's character at one point mocking his pidgin English, which earns Fung's reply, "Oh! You speakee Chinee!" Yuck.I know there are many who argue that these old racist stereotypes have to be taken in context and I think that's true to a certain extent: the blackface/minstrel show stuff is complicated, and has to be seen in the wider context of its crucial role in the growth of American popular song, but outright racial caricatures, in which individuals are mocked just because they are from a particular background, are pretty hard to get around, and this film has several scenes that fall into the genuinely offensive category. Plus, the film itself just isn't that good -- the premise plays out in a frantic, strained fashion, and you have to be a diehard Eleanor Powell fan to appreciate the generally ho-hum choreography, although her hula number is interesting. Anyway, I'll go out on a limb and say that there are plenty of far better '30s comedies, and this one has only modest charms to recommend it. (Axton)
summary: Screwball comedy with a Polynesian setting
Title: N/A

reviewText: This entry is from the tail end of the magnificent Eleanor Powell's reign as the premiere tap dancer of the silver screen.  Unfortunately, there isn't a lot of dancing in evidence here and what there is has lost some of the brilliant sparkle of her previous films, mainly the fault of the choreography.  It's still way ahead of anybody else who was around at the time.  Everybody in the film works very hard to put over the mistaken identity ruse at the center of the plot and you want it to take fine ... but, well, it really looks like they're working hard, perhaps a little too hard. The DVD allows you to skip to the dancing numbers and maybe the Burns and Allen routines.  In this case that's a big plus and I never thought I would say that.  Any one of the Powell 'Broadway Melody' films and, particularly, 'Born To Dance' would be a better way to see her to better advantage.
summary: FOR THE DIE HARD POWELL FANS

reviewText: Robert Young charms, George Burns and Gracie Allen amuse, and Eleanor Powell dances--boy, does she dance! Her hula-in-tap-shoes has to be seen to be believed.The picture is pristine, and the sound is glorious. The storyline is a little weak, but who cares? It's wonderfully entertaining, and lots of fun!

reviewText: This was just good fun to watch. Gracie Allen as Eleanor Powell's girlfriend is just a hoot. Robert Young is charming and one of the better actors of all of her movies. A silly but fun plot of switched identities. And as always she has some great numbers. One Hawaiian Luau style one that's a bit sexy for her!MGM's first fantastic female dancer...its always a pleasure to see her amazing tap dancing..

reviewText: While the plot of this 1939 movie is rather silly - it features Robert Young in a dual role as movie star Brooks Mason and pineapple enterpreneur George Smith - the true star of the film is the great Eleanor Powell, who does several Hawaiian-themed dance numbers, as well as a blackface tribute to her idol, Bill "Bojangles" Robinson.  George Burns plays Mason's (or is it Smith's?) manager in the film, and Gracie Allen plays Powell's dimwitted girlfriend (Gracie and Eleanor even dance together briefly), though Burns and Allen appear separately for most of the picture and only appear together near the end of the movie.  Also in the film:  Eddie "Rochester" Anderson, of Jack Benny fame, plays Brook Mason's butler, Washington.Despite its flaws, if you're an Eleanor Powell fan, this movie is a must-have.
summary: Silly plot, but Eleanor Powell steals the show again
